commentBody: Smashed my PB by 45 seconds. Way too easy for a Friday
It's not Spidey Sense?

A few nice entries, but this was Tuesday-level difficulty.

3.5/10
I finished that one with an EASYA

I already see a trend forming in these comments, so I'll offer the opposite perspective: I really enjoyed this! A bit challenging, but not intimidatingly so. 

I know some folks look forward to more difficult puzzles at the end of the week, so I can see why they may be disappointed, but this was fun for me. Great first puzzle for the constructor, too!

I got a bit lucky and finished in under 18 minutes.  Good time, for me. Not too many proper nouns. Good, original cluing with not very much crosswordese.  No Oreos and olios or oleos today. Only an orca.
I really enjoyed this. It felt like gradually weaving something lovely into a whole. Bravo!
Not too hard for a Friday puzzle. Finished six minutes faster than my average. Still, I found it enjoyable.
Surprisingly easy for a Friday, not that I‚Äôm complaining. (Definitely not complaining.)

Blurry photos make me shutter.

(I can develop more puns in a flash.)

Great job folks. 

I just want to take it all in. Click. Mental picture. 

Name that friends episode.

Maybe Wednesday level - 9:16, which is 8 minutes less than prior PB!  Expect Saturday will be ‚Äúrough‚Äù

PS Clearly it is spidey sense.  Surprising that a college student would have tried to sneak that by.  Should not have made it past edit.

Far too easy for a Friday. I wonder what the  process is for selecting puzzles for Friday and Saturday. Who would look at this one and decide that it's a Friday puzzle instead of the Tuesday or Wednesday level puzzle that it clearly is.

Agree with the comments that call out SPIDERSENSE. Spidey-sense is what it's called. Don't think I've ever heard it called spider sense in the MCU or any other medium. But good luck clueing OYLESS. "What your Jewish mother says when you're being a bit much?"

Otherwise, a perfectly good puzzle. A bit underwhelming for a Friday, but probably not bad for a new constructor.

Yes, it was breezy for a Friday, as most people agree, but it was also sunny and original. Difficulty is certainly not the only metric by which to judge these things. 

I especially enjoyed 29 across; as Wednesday‚Äôs crossword taught us (60 across), the little bugs populating the rebus squares on Thursday‚Äôs crossword will ‚Äúfarm‚Äù today‚Äôs sap suckers for their honeydew! Obviously they don‚Äôt have udders, so the ants will stroke them with their antennae to stimulate honeydew excretion. 

I also enjoyed ‚Äúliterally grilled meat.‚Äù So often, a generic Spanish term is used in English to denote a very specific preparation or variety. Salsa is just ‚Äúsauce,‚Äù queso is literally every ‚Äúcheese,‚Äù sombrero is any old ‚Äúhat,‚Äù and yes, carne asada literally means grilled meat. Which is fine ‚Äî there‚Äôs good reason for that. But it‚Äôs a good reminder that if you go to, say, Argentina and ask for carne asada, there will be zero Mexican seasonings on it.
Congratulations on your debut, Abigail! The right amount of challenge for my Friday brain and an enjoyable solve. Looking forward to your themed puzzle debut.

A most enjoyable Friday from Abigail Martin. We Are really looking forward to future puzzles. Those long downs were intimidating but suss-able. And Street Food,  Hot Cereal, and Carne Asada are among my favorite things, more Or Less. New Release? Bravo!

I have a 7-day streak with NO lookups! What is happening? 

I think the emus are plotting something for tomorrow!
üí≠ When will someone give us an emu emoji? üí≠

Solid puzzle, made remarkable by learning it's a debut.  Very little cheap fill and it's sort of nice to see Ora without Rita for a change.  But I must join the chorus who reluctantly changed that Y to accommodate Peter's non-existent sense.  Must be his different and more proper variant in the spiderverse.
New Friday best, just under 8 minutes

Acting all ROUGH . . .

I PITHS the STREETFOOD that ain't CARNEASADA!

Really fresh, sparkling fill, which made up for the editors‚Äô decision to not run this really neat puzzle a couple of days earlier in the week. 

SPIDEySENSE was a last-minute correction after I decided that maybe I‚Äôve never seen a sale sign proclaiming ‚ÄúOy! LESS!‚Äù after all. 

Mmm, street food. We had my cousin (√•tte times removed) from the Land of the Midnight Sun down for the weekend with her family just a few days back. We were all moseying around town and came across a Mexican restaurant with outdoor seating. Rain poured down all around us as we sat under an umbrella and ordered plates and plates of street tacos, quesadillas, and nachos to go with pitchers of beer for us and Mexican lemonade for the kiddos. It wasn‚Äôt quite food-truck food, but it came very close. Most importantly, my pale-faced, reared-on-lutefisk cousins couldn‚Äôt hack the hot, freshly made mango and pineapple salsa and it was mine, all mine, its tangy bite calling to mind my own land: the Land of Enchantment. New Mexico, I miss you so. 

On this homesick, maudlin note, I‚Äôm signing off to go grind the morning beans. Abigail‚Äôs puzzle has made me too hungry to go back to sleep.
I enjoyed this, Abigail. I‚Äôm looking forward to your next offering.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aphid Wow, APHIDs are really interesting! I went down a bit of a rabbit hole: Populations are often entirely female and they can give birth to pregnant females. And some species ‚Ä¶ ‚Äúcan produce up to 41 generations of females in a season. Thus, one female hatched in spring can theoretically produce billions of descendants, were they all to survive.‚Äù (A generation typically living 20 to 40 days.) I know they can be a pain in the garden, especially if you love artichokes, but it‚Äôs hard not to give them some respect!
The first friday i ever completed! 47 minutes feels embarrassing compared to others here. One day I will join your superfast ranks!
Phish-monger was the very last answer I got. I kept thinking it was about the band, so I kept thinking jam artist? No that doesn‚Äôt fit.
Spidey Sense not Spider Sense :)

Very entertaining Friday puzzle. I know carne asada is grilled meat, but second day of a new year as a teacher and I had a bit of brain fog. We have seders and iftar as well as all the food. Made me hungry.  As a musician I wanted new music instead of new release. I won‚Äôt add anything regarding a certain web slinger as that‚Äôs been over stated already. Look forward to more puzzles Abigail.

Very nice debut! Congrats on making the NYT constructors' roster, and hope to see more from you in the future.

Thanks, Abigail!

Sometimes solvers sound like boxers, wearing satin trunks, doing vigorous knee-bends in their corner of the ring, and they were ready to come out swinging. 

Puzzles should be judged by their merits, not by how long they take or whether they're deemed appropriate for a day of the week.  

They're puzzles.  Sometimes easy, sometimes not, and if it's more fun for you to see it as contest, fine, but pot shots and caviling about it aren't relevant or appropriate.

Abigail Martin has debuted with an interesting, original puzzle. I had fun solving it and needed some of the crosses to help me complete it.  That's pretty much what I came for.  

Thank you, Abigail.

I solved this quite enjoyable but not particularly challenging puzzle in Tuesday/Wednesday time, but I was almost defeated by the NE corner: stacking CNBC, MWAH, COHEN, AERO and PATREON was unintentionally cruel for a solver like me. Thankfully the educated guess of AERO and realization of MWAH gave me crosses to get BRAVO, that V gave me SERVE, and then I was able to deal with the rest.

I did not comment yesterday or the day before, travelling around Mazowsze P√≥≈Çnocne (Northern Mazovia) with my father, but I did solve the puzzles. I especially enjoyed the pure siliness of parsing TENANTS as TEN ANTS on Thursday - there was something Monthy-Pythonesque and liberating about it.

TRAY crossing PHISH can‚Äôt be a coincidence. 

The only thing that takes me longer than a weekend puzzle is getting through a TReY Anastasio guitar solo. 

üéπüé∏‚≠ïÔ∏èüåµ

Congratulations on an amusing NYT debut, Ms Martin!

Good luck with your remaining studies. I hope we‚Äôll see you back here soon.

Congratulations on your NEW RELEASE, Abigail. I enjoyed it. 

I had not me before WE ARE and green before ROUGH. And of course I also had SPIDEy SENSE before SPIDER. I‚Äôm not sure why people think this should have run on a different day. It‚Äôs a non-themed puzzle, so it wouldn‚Äôt run before a Friday. My solve time was under my average but over my PB. Not bad, especially for a debut. I‚Äôm a happy camper heading into my weekend on the Cape.

This was a really good puzzle, and a great debut, so hearty congratulations to you, Abigail!

My biggest flub was quickly filling in "marathonrace" for 21D.  Even though that seemed a bit redundant, I mean we're talking about Kenyans, right?

I did not know there were two kinds of steeple chase. I only knew of the one involving horses.  I didn't know about the one involving Kenyans.

But, to repeat for emphasis, nice puzzle Ms Martin.
Much better offering than yesterdays ant ridden conundrum. Tricky but very doable. Congrats on your debut. Enjoyed it
Don‚Äôt ask me how I know, but ‚Äúwakeup‚Äù has the same number of letters as BEREAL, and ‚Äúbreakfast‚Äù has the same number of letters as HOTCEREAL.
Has ORA ever been "Part of a New Zealander's greeting"?

I thought it was a great puzzle.    My hangups were "Piths"/"itch" (my mind kept wanting 'urge' for 2D).  AsTo for InRe in 5A.   Great for Bravo in 12D.  And Tased for Lased in 38A.    Despite those hangups slowing me down I still came in at 25 minutes -> just under half my Friday average.   

One very nice touch in the puzzle was the parallel words - both visually and in meaning - in 30D and 21D.  To get two answers related to horse racing in those two lengthy downs, with neither of the clues having having anything to do with horse racing, was just a really nice touch that I appreciated.       Thank you for the very enjoyable puzzle Abigail Martin (and of course to Will Shortz for his consistently fantastic job as editor).
Great debut puzzle!!

In UK we say ‚Äòpopped‚Äô when you go out for a bit, I.e ‚Äòpopped to the shops‚Äô, which got me stuck on 25 Across. Especially when you think pAIL is an Americanism and misremember oPPA as the father figure!

P. S.

Wondering why we haven't seen Barry the last couple days.  

Anyone have the 411 on that?  (I'm very street.)

Friday brag: I did it in 42:34 without looking at any of the Down clues, only crosses! The saving graces for me were the long and guessable down clues like S__WEEDSA_AD and S_E_PL__HA_E, which totally helped fill in a lot of the gaps. SE corner was the hardest because I don‚Äôt know my Bible so I hazarded Eli instead of LOT, which knocked me off course for a while, and couldn‚Äôt get ‚Äúgreen‚Äù out of my head when I needed ROUGH. Got there In the end!

Great puzzle!

This was a very nice and breezy Friday!

Though I find it a bit funny that I've never heard of oatmeal referred to as HOTCEREAL while living in a country that practically lives on it.

I wonder, how does the rest of the world take their oatmeal?

Here, it's most often eaten with a little knob of butter and some fruit jam. If I make it at home, I'll put some fresh fruit instead, or frozen berries everyone has stocked up in their freezer, left over from the summer foraging :)

NAPPED not POPPED, garrgh....

Thanks for the puzzle!

Lovely crossword.
I keep forgetting my American slang - PEACE used as a farewell, use of BE REAL and HORSE RACE but crossers were helpful.

Congratulations on your first NYT crossword.
An easy peasy Friday filler-inner. But I do kind of miss the ants.
Enjoyed this one very much! Whole solve flowed nicely.
SPIDEY SENSE, no?
The easy mode version of this crossword was pleasant, it gave me some confidence to try the "regular" version during the weekend. https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/paid/easy-mode-110

Hello all. I really enjoyed this puzzle. Terrific long entries, fun and inventive, almost no fill. BRAVO, Abigail! I‚Äôve liked all the puzzles this week especially yesterday‚Äôs ants. I‚Äôm now on a 13 day streak! üíÉ 

I live in the part of Queens where Peter Parker is from. Our Trader Joe‚Äôs is Spiderman-themed. And just for the record, I‚Äôm okay with SPIDER SENSE.

My husband wants to take me to Star Wars movies (yawn). He wants to take me to LOTR movies (yawn). He wants to take me to MCU movies‚Äîwait, a big group of good-looking guys with tight comedy? Okay, I‚Äôll go to those.

Thursday's lightning-fast solve and today's easy romp makes me fear that Saturday's will be a beast.

While the long entries and the puzzle overall were very good, I miss Robyn Weintraub's Friday puzzles, as well as all the other regular and storied constructors I've come to know and love over the years. They've gone on to other more hospitable sites. Frankly, am getting very tired of all these debuts. I'm probably the only one. I did appreciate the lack of rap artists and multiple sports clues in this offering. Guess the NYT wants to save money, since they pay newbies less. Rant over.

Dear Friday,

Please return my puzzle. 

tc

Unusually enjoyable Friday puzzle. Not all that easy for me, of course, and I did have to look up a couple of things. But then it was just a lot of pondering and working the crosses until something finally dawned on me. Oh, and I'm about 15 miles west of our constructor's college. 

An off-topic joke inspired by 47d. During my time in Vietnam we were in the far north and often not far from the border of LAOS. That led me to recall one funny moment. After a long day trekking through the jungle, we had camped for the night on a hilltop. When we got up the next morning, one of the guys looked out to the east and said, "Oh, wow. You can see the gulf from here!" And one other guy said, "Really? Can you see Hue out there?"

To which he replied... "Oh yeah, way, way out there." 

Some interesting puzzle finds today, all with somewhat similar tricks. I'll put those in replies.

....

I noticed some interesting pairs in today‚Äôs puzzle:
CAMERA READY and PHOTO SHOOT, HORSE RACE and STEEPLECHASE, CNBC and BRAVO (with a side of Andy COHEN).

I also liked to see SEDERS and IFTAR sharing the same puzzle. And if there really is a pairing theme, maybe the presence of APHIDs will stop a little of the SPIDER SENSE grousing.

I enjoyed this one. BRAVO, Abigail. (Yeah, I know it should be ‚Äúbrava‚Äù, I‚Äôm just using what I was given. üôÉ)

SPIDEY SENSE.
I choose this hill to die on.

I do love a themeless.
Something about the freedom of a grid
that doesn‚Äôt need to contort itself
into any yoga poses
to fit the themers.

And that after filling in an answer, 
the next is a new ballgame!
No getting comfy.

Crossing fingers for a really chewy,
crunchy, gnarly Saturday.

Congratulations on your debut Abigail!
Ending with TADA. 
Nailed it.
SPIDEY SENSE, come on y‚Äôall.
Really great Friday puzzle that felt particularly fresh in every way.

Almost a themed Friday, since all the long entries were two-word phrases.

A bit too gently clued for my taste, but a solid debut puzzle. Finished in about half my typical Friday time.

Like many others I expect, I had SPIDEYSENSE.

PEACE.

STEEPLECHASE is an Olympic event? 

Things you learn at the crosswords.

Friendly cluing and this one was my best Friday time in a long while 

Nice Job!

Fun one today. Not close to my Friday best, a little better than yesterday, but way ahead of M,T,W this week. No complaints about the level of difficulty. My holdup was the NW corner. I misquoted Laertes with "his", which blocked any of the crosses for the longest time. Living in Vermont, the [Phish] reference got me. Fans might be saddened to know that this week it was announced that Nectar's, where they got their start many years ago, has closed for good. https://vtdigger.org/2025/07/31/burlington-music-venue-nectars-closes-after-50-year-run/ Lots of non-trite fill, which is part of what made this one fun. I particularly enjoyed the CEREAL/BEREAL juxtaposition. Would it be wrong to note the occurrence of the answer to 41D in one of today's other puzzles? Thanks and congratulations, Abigail!
APRIL is not a season
Hand up for SPIDEySENSE and ACCESSRamp in an otherwise smooth solve.  Congratulations on your NYT debut Abigail Martin and hope to see more.

It‚Äôs really interesting how many people are complaining about SPIDERSENSE, even to the point of calling for the puzzle‚Äôs retraction. The official term is, in fact, SPIDERSENSE. SPIDEySENSE is a bit like referring to the old MS Office mascot as ‚ÄúClippy‚Äù instead of his actual name, Clippit.
It took me only ten years, but all of the sudden I'm cruising through many Fridays and Saturdays without lookups. Loved it! Congrats on a great debut.

Confession:
I had ROUG_, and thought to myself, "What does ROUGe have to do with playing golf?  Is there another meaning to 'golf' that I'm not aware of?"
And I had to get the H from the cross.
What a great debut, Ms. Martin! I zipped through the east side. Loved it. Thanks!

Good job Abigail, and thanks! I am on fire today -- raced through this puzzle AND the Bee AND Connections AND Strands AND the Mini. This has never happened before and probly won't again, so I had to humble-brag just this once. Sorry...
I seem to be in the minority ‚Äî I found this boring and disappointingly easy for a Friday
This was what I came here to say. :)
The unique filler and interesting clues more than makes up for a relatively easier Friday. Very enjoyable puzzle today.
I caught all those little references to Hamlet in your puzzle today, Abagail! Well done! Directing a production of that play at the moment, and it was a wonderful surprise!

A lot of new-to-me factoids here!  Ramadan meal; defense scty all those years ago; track event (Don't the Kenyans win them all??); what it was that bonked Chicken Little; Korean DaDa; and I thought that was SPIDEY SENSE!!

Also, who goes around pluralizing PITH?

TAZED before LASED.

That's about it.  I've been up since 3:11a.m. CDT (against my will, but the sneeze attack was spectacular! And then my nose ran for the next hour.)  So I did the Wordle (tsk-5) and the Bee (Genius + as per usual) and tried to avoid reading the news.  Met my walking buddy at 6:30 for a taste of Purgatory.  In my second set of clothes and upping the coffee intake.  
All y'all stay safe and find the high ground.

Congrats on the debut! This was great!

So much fun fill: SCAM ARTIST, SEAWEED SALAD, CARNE ASADA, both SEDER and IFTAR, SPIDER SENSE. I'm amazed at how little glue there was, especially considering this is a debut.

I'm now convinced that ORCA is the Oreo of the animal world.

I often laze when I‚Äôm sapped.

Great puzzle. I‚Äôm guessing all the hard line day-of-weekers also get steamed if they see a Ford Taurus in October?
After squashing yesterday's anthill, today felt like a pith of cake. Bravo!
Fabulously fun and quick. Great debut!
Awesome debut, Aubrey!

40A made me think of this song: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=hWaw-tQ4W7w&pp=ygUaZm9yIGVhY2ggY2hpbGQgdGhhdCdzIGJvcm4%3D if that doesn't work just put in 40A or For each child that's born, a morning star rises And sings to the universe who 40A

I had SPIDEYSENSE for a while, but couldn‚Äôt quite get OYLESS referring to a sale. 

L
I thought it was SPIDEY sense....
Nice one! Especially for a debut. Why was I thinking OKRA instead of old favorite ORCA?? üòÇ All solved in the end!

[Street food?]

I thought this was a really fresh puzzle. And not as easy as many here found it. Brava.

(My aranea sense told me one entry would weave a tangled web of discontent)



ROADKILL

This puzzle was a Rambling Wreck! (My sister and her husband went to GaTech for grad school. Beat UGA!)

I was not familiar with PATREON. (Not a brand of tequila.) Did we need an alternative to Substack? IIRC, that was the alternative to Twitter, which was happily de-platforming (and de-monetizing) anyone who didn't follow the orthodoxy on COVID policy. Apparently, Substack has gotten too "social."

I solved this from the bottom up, which is typical for me - then I got stuck in the northwest, finding it hard to get to the PITH of the matter as I was stuck on urge instead of ITCH - although I thought PulpS was a stretch, it was the best I could do until after a Spelling Bee break.

Never knew STEEPLECHASE could be a race for humans. It was only a few years ago that I learned that the name came from racing from steeple to steeple, steeples being the most visible outcroppings in the countryside.
My spidey sense is telling me we'll see more of Abigail. Nice initial Frday!

I, like many, had SPIDEySENSE....But, oy vey, I had to change it to an R.
TGIF - hope no one here was too affected by yesterday's storms. Here in NL CT, not much rain. BUT wow - a lovely walk this morning at 63 deg.
Can confidently say I have never known that those stringy orange bits are called PITHS. Learned something new!

Nice job Abigail. Go Dawgs! üòâ(Tech is not known for their football team, although they forced last seasons‚Äô  game with UGA into 8 overtimes). It's just clean, old-fashioned hate. (Look it up).

Phish-Monger definitely drew me to the jam band, as I'm reminded of yesterday's brief LACUNA COIL exchange with Cindy, the Phan.

The ‚ÄúMedieval characters‚Äù was a great misdirection, one of several in today's puzzle. I enjoy those even more than I do rebussesses.

Golf-related clues are always chuckle-worthy . For the Golf course part‚Ä¶ ‚Äúwoods‚Äù fit nicely, ‚Äúwater trap‚Äù did not. Water seems to have a magnetic quality on a golf course. It attracts geese, ducks, gators (in Fla) and the invasive Titelist. I do occasionally celebrate the ball landing on the first cut of rough on my approach shot, so not all is lost. I usually reach the green in par.

Are yesterday's ants theme, the previous day‚Äôs Oreos tied to Spider sense?

I'm almost afraid to ask how Identify as = peg. I get the ‚ÄúI had him pegged as just another angry liberal‚Äù (as an example üòâ). Or wooden pegs, etc. Sorry, I'm not feeling the clue/solution here.

Seaweed salad, or the inspiration for dental floss, is pretty good, but I much prefer the Korean Bibimbap over the Hawaiian Poke bowl. Just not my taste, that's all.

An exciting announcement from a musician ‚ÄúI'm ditching the bagpipe lessons for the kazoo.‚Äù Or, ‚Äúhey, this amp goes up to an 11. I can mic the bagpipes now.‚Äù

Peace, y'all'ins.
What's a "patreon"?
There is actually a name for the string thingys in an orange? I guess I will have to live a few more years before I know everything.

What a great debut! I finished a bit under my average, once I figured out a ROSEPETAL was more appropriate than red ribbon, and that "men's marathon" wouldn't fit the crosses for STEEPLECHASE. 

Oh, yes: the crosses! They crossed me up more than a couple times, to be sure. But as Deb says, the puzzle had great fill, and not too much esoterica (for me).
FINALLY!  Finally got the work week sweep.  First ever 5 day in a road gold star.  Feels goodüòÑ

After every solved puzzle I do two things, I clear the board and solve it again then I look at how long it took Rex to solve it.

I do the first to reinforce answers with clues. I do the latter to torture myself.

STEEPLECHASE and LASED did me in. 
An otherwise fun puzzle!

Is this the right place to comment on the August bonus puzzle? There‚Äôs an error in the clue for 65A. That is the name of the novel in question, but it‚Äôs a different character that speaks that line.  Finally my years of watching all these Jane Austen movies pays off, confirmed by checking the text!

Like I‚Äôm sure others did, i had ‚Äúkeep trying‚Äô‚Ä¶‚Äù with SPIDEYSENSE‚Äù upon completion. For some reason, OYLESS made sense to me, like‚ÄùOy, I have to mark this down in order to move it!‚Äù Mind, oy could be substituted for aiya or drats or any other exclamation of dismay.
I tried to put "TOYATATHON" for the [beginning of Taurus season] :D
C'mon, everyone knows it's SPIDEY sense.

I wondered if I could extend my non-Autocheck streak another day. By the time I had to quit and go to bed I had the left-bottom triangle, a bit more than half the puzzle, filled with wild guesses in Pencil, many of which made no sense to me. I kept telling myself that I should switch to Autocheck and stop wasting time. I was about to do so when I suddenly wondered, looking at my ___E___CHASE at 21D, could STEEPLECHASE be something Kenyans might do. I filled that in and shut down for the night.

I started seeing more possibilities this morning, like F in front of my -OOD at the end of 14A. That led to one of my many lookups: "ramadan if" and Bingo! I could fill in three possible Acrosses, like STREETFOOD. Another very beneficial lookup was "american greed." The resulting four letters were good clues to finishing the Downs they started. My very last letter was a likely N for COHEN, supported by a lookup of the unlikely word PATREON saying it was real. So, with all those lookups it's silly to claim a streak, but I'm going to say I added a sixth day to my "streak" in an incredibly speedy 1:25:14 (with lots of interruptions).
Best time yet for a Friday! I did have SpAM before SCAM in 17A before the downs fixed that. Nice debut, Ms Martin!
How nice to have Iftar and seder in the same puzzle.

Really good Friday for me.  I learned a few things and knew some things I didn't know I knew. 

I'm looking forward to more grids from Ms Martin.
Absolutely flew through this one to get the gold star in 6:28. Would have liked a bit more of a challenge but it was still a fun solve regardless.

I was getting bogged down early, so I didn't pay attention to speed at all. Then everything opened up for me and suddenly I was done, a few seconds over my PB. Would have easily been a PB if I had focused.

Although it took me 7 minutes longer than my average I cannot believe I finished this without lookups. After my first pass across and down the board was pretty empty‚Ä¶ But word by word I made it. 

Tough Friday (for me)
If you have an hour--or even eight minutes--to spend in Italy, why not spend it with Ludovico? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x1aReZsmVjw&list=RDx1aReZsmVjw&start_radio=1
Nice breezy Friday with very reasonable long clues.  A nice foray into Friday if you're just starting out with a lack of crosswordese. Thanks for the puzzle!

Add me to the surprisingly quick list. I would have beaten my Monday average if our Korean DiL hadn‚Äôt gone off to yoga. 

I heartily agree with the other Kevin that competency kind of sneaks up on us over the years. Add wheelhouse to the mix, and possibly a posse, and you can have a Friday miracle. I did.
At first I thought 17A was RECORD SHOP, but I guess those aren‚Äôt really a thing anymore. üò¢

Congrats to Ms. Martin on her debut puzzle! And for being a cool person (my evidence is that she knits and crochets). I enjoyed the puzzle and got through it in reasonable time inspite of having EDAMAMEBEANS instead of SEAWEEDSALAD. My only quibble is SPIDERSENSE instead of SPIDEYSENSE. For the longest time I tried to make OYLESS make sense for the cross. Oy!

Wow! A sub 20 minute Friday with no lookups! Very unusual for me. Proud of myself... before I see all the comments saying it was easy. 

But shouldn't it be SPIDEySENSE??
I also don't really like BEREAL. The phrase is get real.

20m 02s. This was speedy for me. (Haha, I realize some of you did this in less than 10 m.)

After yesterday and today,seems like we are due for something more challenging. 

My observation: a number of the clues were very straightforward.  I am neither a genius nor well read or a traveller. Straightforward clues for me are everyday words, concepts, people, etc.

It was fun, but I would have liked more challenging clues.
I was a little put off by spider sense instead of spidey sense. really?!?

a seder celebrates exodus
with a symbolic repast
while muslims relish an iftar
after a ramadan fast

üßµI don‚Äôt know, and I haven‚Äôt read through the comments, but the Marvel Universe sense I know is SPIDEY-SENSE.

That‚Äôs what makes Spider-Man so relatable: His humorous, easy-going, boy-next-door demeanor.

üßµLet me put it this way, in the whole SPIDEY-SPIDER debate:

I can accept SPIDERüï∑Ô∏è, if I see a citation or discussion about the sense.

At a fair a guy sees a stall where a woman is offering advice, for 1$ and for 100$. He's feeling cheap so he asks for 1$ advice.
'When it's raining, take an umbrella ,' the woman says.
'What kind of advice is that,' the guys says. 'Everybody knows that!'
'Well, what did you expect for 1$?'
So the guy asks hands over 100$.
The woman leans in and says:
'Bro, open a stall like mine.'

Congratulations on your first Friday puzzle completion! I stopped focusing on time when I realized that rushing through a puzzle was taking the joy out of solving. I love taking time to admire clever clues, well constructed grids and all the new things I learn along the way.  I avoid comparing myself to other solvers because we all come to the puzzles with unique experiences and knowledge that either helps us or slows us down. Forget the time, enjoy the solve!

@dutchiris But it's an explicit feature of the NYT crossword that it gets harder as the week goes on - that's part of the puzzle's DNA. So for a lot of us "difficulty" is one of many valid criteria by which to judge a puzzle. It shouldn't be the sole measure of a puzzle's success, but it's hardly irrelevant or inappropriate to comment on difficulty when its an inherent part of the way the NYT puzzle is set up and presented to solvers.
@dutchiris Well said.

@Arthurs If you work puzzles in the archive going many years back, you'll find that the difficulty level on any day of the week was much higher than now. Follow the  money. The NYT wants as many subscribers as possible. They cut the paper into pieces and sell them individually. Games are revenue. Easier sells better than harder. So expecting that former level of difficulty is going to result in a lot of disappointment. It's been modified genetically for financial survival. Evolution, it'll get ya every time.
@Gina D It's strange to agree with you as well as with the original comment.
@MExpat strangely,  I feel the same way.
@Arthurs Bingo, well said.

@Arthurs

I'd love to see a scatterplot of how each solver rates the difficulty of a puzzle on a given day. Even if the editors had perfect foresight and the trend line for every week went steadily upward, I know my own data points would be all over the place. There is no way I can judge a puzzle's place on some theoretically desirable weekly trend line by my own individual measure of its difficulty. And judging by comments in this space, this appears to be generally true--invariably when a bunch of people find a puzzle easy, others will find it unusually difficult. 

We are not promised that the puzzles will get steadily harder for each one of us, or even for the solving public as an aggregate, but that they will _generally_ get harder as a week progresses. I find that to be true. 

And if there were no outliers, no surprises, wouldn't things get boring?

@dutchiris I agree wholeheartedly with your fourth paragraph. For me, this was a fun, interesting puzzle that felt fresh. It wasn't just a typing contest; I needed the crosses to figure some things out. 

I finished with my best Friday time, but so what? I view that as making up for last week, when I went to another tab without stopping the timer (oops!) and ended up with a seven hour solve.

My problem with track and field is that I often don't get a good look at the events which really fascinate me:  the hammer, the discus, and the shot.

I mean, for my money, if you've seen one foot race you've seen them all.

@Francis

Yeah, I feel your pain. I enjoy watching sprints but 5k and 10k are so boring, except the final lap. There will be so much going on at the stadium: decathlon, heptathlon, high jump, long jump, shot put, but nooooo, they'll be showing the 10k on TV... Sigh.

@Andrzej

One could say the same thing about watching a stage of the Tour de France but I personally wouldn‚Äôt. 

The Tour is televised in the US from start to finish each day which might sound kinda boring, particularly in a sprint stage finish (as opposed to a mountain top finish) where all the ‚Äúaction‚Äù occurs in the last two minutes. 

However, I find watching the whole stage an engrossing experience. The strategy evident from start to finish by the various cycling teams is worth my time commitment. I also marvel at the physical effort required throughout the stage. 

From my vantage point, the same can be said about longer track events. 

YMMV

@Richard

I used to watch whole stages of the Giro, Tour and Vuelta, and I enjoyed it - for the banter of the commentators, and the scenery much more so than for the sport :D

The thing about long races at track and field meets is that they are (for me) the least dynamic and interesting of all the events, yet for some reason showing them takes precedence over all the others. 15 or 30 minutes of people running in circles has nothing on the dynamic efforts of the other athletes. 800m and the 4x400m relay are the longest of the races I'm usually interested in.

I have watched marathons, a few times, but I would never choose one over, say, a pole vault competition, if they were both being shown live at the same time.

@Andrzej

I'm old enough to remember going to Steeplechase Park as a young child. It was an amusement park in Coney Island that first opened in 1897. It was created by George C. Tilyou, an entrepreneur who based it on based on his innovative idea of a gravity-powered horse race ride. The amusement park finally closed in 1964, but I remember it so well, even if I was too scared to go on its most famous ride, the Parachute Jump. Google it to see some interesting pictures.

@Andrzej

In person track and field is the best as there is always something to watch. I also get frustrated by TV coverage but for some overlapping and some opposing reasons. The triple jump never gets as much coverage as I want and the commentators rarely know what they are talking about when it is shown. For races, I find the sprints less dynamic and interesting than the distances as in the sprints they‚Äôre either faster or they‚Äôre not. In the longer races I get to see the strategy, tactics, and force of will to push past fatigue. (Hurdles are interesting too for the technique involved) My favorite race to watch in university was the 4 x 800, not too long but long enough for tactics to matter and to see the grit needed for a good kick.

@Sonja

In our house every morning is ‚Äòpuuro aika‚Äô, our son can‚Äôt get enough of it, although the blueberries we can get in the UK (I believe Finns call them pensasmistikoita) aren‚Äôt a patch on the ones in Finland. Needless to say, Mummo‚Äôs porridge is always best :)

@Sonja

Recently overnight oats have become popular here, and you eat those cold. My wife will sometimes make them when she knows she won't have time for breakfast at home before work and she wants to eat at the office. She also made them several times for me, and I enjoyed them.

Traditionally, porrige (owsianka in Polish; owies is oats) will be served hot, though. I cook my oats in milk (using water never crossed my mind - how bland the result must be!), and add whatever I feel like: something for sweetness, like sugar or honey, and possibly something for taste on top of the milk, like fruit, usually berries.

BTW, we don't really have the equivalent of the word "cereal" as a type of food in Polish. P≈Çatki (flakes) is what we call most cereals: p≈Çatki kukurydziane (cornflakes), p≈Çatki owsiane (the oat flakes you use for porrige). American-style cereal was practically unknown in Poland before democracy and market economy. We've been eat porrige for centuries though, obviously. Kaszka manna (farina/semolina in English, I think) has always been popular, too. Manna is straight from the biblical Exodus, and kaszka means "tiny groats."

@Sonja Oatmeal is one of several hot cereals, including grits, cream of rice, cream of wheat and maybe more. There are variants of cold cereals made from oats, like Cheerios or granola. Anyway, yeah, we do sort of lump it as a hot cereal. I want to like oatmeal, but I can‚Äôt do it. It‚Äôs a textural thing‚Ä¶
Y‚Äôall: Muesli!

and I‚Äôm a happy camper.

@Mean Old Lady

I love reading your posts too, MOL. Always look for them early one. And... I'll share one more kind of funny story from my time over there. 

We'd been in a lot of combat and had gotten the nickname "hard-luck Alpha." After one stressful time out in the jungle they sent us to a firebase, saying - "This is a safe place; hasn't been attacked in months." And... of course we got hit the first night we were there. A long, long fight but we managed to drive them off. 

The next morning, the three of us who were left in my squad spent a couple of hours with others going around and picking up bodies and putting them in cargo nets to be hauled back to the rear. When we were finally done, we sat down for our usual smoke break, and one of the other guys turned his pack on its side and read: 

"Warning. Smoking may be hazardous to your health." 

And we all collapsed on the ground laughing. That's a long time reminder to me that everything is a matter of perspective. 

...

It's a basic track race with the exception of a combined hurdle and water jump usually placed just inside the track at the middle of the first curve. The first quarter mile is run on the track as usual, then the course is changed to involve the jump.

@Dave Botanical Nerd Word of the week: Hesperidium: The berry of a citrus plant (Rutaceae), i.e. a fruit whose fleshy parts are divided into segments, the whole being surrounded by a separable skin.* Fruits in the citrus family (Rutaceae) such as oranges, lemons, limes, grapefruits, kumquats, and clementines are all examples of hesperidia. @Zach

Record shops exist, but they‚Äôre relatively hard to find. More to the point, late-week puzzles often contain answers that are not what comes to most people‚Äôs minds first. 

There have been a lot of new solvers to these puzzles, and the learning curve is slow. A classic example of this is the fact that seemingly half of the nitpicking today is about SPIDER SENSE. But if you look into it, that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs actually called by the cognoscenti (not claiming to be one, but I did a little Googling when that came up). Sure, most people know the other version of it, but it‚Äôs Friday, and the answer is likely not to be what you think of first. 

Understanding this is a key part of being able to do the higher difficulty puzzles. Griping about it, on the other hand, is counterproductive.

@Andrzej

I don't think my IQ has ever been measured.  If it was, the information was never relayed to me.

But I can tell you this, I was a competitive kid, especially on tests.  I took every one as if my very future depended on it.

But I got a real shock in the seventh and eighth grades.  They gave these tests to a subset of seventh graders, ones the teachers had chosen, probably for classroom performance.

I scored in the top three in all categories, science, spelling, math, etc.

*Next* year, everyone took the test.  I scored third on one category, and out of the money on the rest.

I think that's when my Imposter Syndrome set in for good.
